cards.question: Name some of the benefits of Java
cards.answer: Object oriented, encapsulation, memory management (less prone to memory leaks), huge library, secure by design (jvm sandbox), write once run anywhere, strongly typed, multithreaded, distributed computing

cards.question: These are valid identifiers true or false: $objectOne, 1$objectTwo, _Object3
cards.answer: false, identifiers can begin with letter, currency character or connecting character like underscore, but not a digit

cards.question: These are valid identifiers true or false: $ObjectOne, _ObjectTwo, someObject3, someOtherObject$$99
cards.answer: true, identifiers can begin with letter, currency character or connecting character like underscore, but not a digit

cards.question: Valid identifier? : int :b;
Valid identifier? : int -d;
Valid identifier: int e#;
Valid identifier: int ______2_w;
Valid identifier? int $c;
Valid identifier? int 2nbr;
Valid keyword: default
Valid keyword: strictfp
T/F : There can be only one public class per source file?
T/F: Classes can be made private?
if there is a public class does the file name have to match True/False
Files can contain multiple classes true/false
package name has to be first line if file is in a package t/f
T/F Multiple classes in one file can have their own package and imports?
cards.answer: false, each file can only have 1 unique package and set of imports

cards.question: T/F main() can be overloaded?
java.util.* is valid?
cards.answer: true, it allows all class in util to be used without specifying java.util.ClassName

cards.question: This this a valid import line? static import java.lang.System.out;
cards.answer: false, import must be first identifier

cards.question: import java.* is valid?
Name the access modifiers?
Name the access controls?
Name the non-access modifiers
Name the two access controls a class may use?
T/F Default Access is the same as package level access?
T/F strictfp can be used with final?
T/F Classes can be both final and abstract
cards.answer: False, these are two separate concepts, abstract classes must be extended, final means you can not extend it

cards.question: T/F strictfp is a keyword and can be used to modify a class and a method but never a variable
T/F A final keyword on a class means it can be subclassed?
cards.answer: False, final means it can NOT be subclassed.

cards.question: T/F An abstract class can never be instantiated?
Abstract classes can be executed.
cards.answer: True, they can have public static void main and it can execute with java AbstractClass

cards.question: T/F Abstract can be applied to variables
cards.answer: False, abstract can apply to classes and methods only

cards.question: T/F Abstract methods end in semicolon instead of curly brackets.
T/F An interface is considered a contract
T/F Abstract keyword must be applied to method signatures in the interface
cards.answer: False, they are presumed if not specified

cards.question: T/F Interfaces can have private methods
cards.answer: False, methods must be public only

cards.question: T/F Inteface methods are implicitly public and abstract?
T/F Interfaces can only declare constants aka public static final and not instance variables.
cards.answer: True; you can not create instance style variables in an interface.

cards.question: T/F Interface methods can not be marked final, strictfp, or native
T/F An interface can extend one or more other interfaces
cards.answer: True; it just can not anything else and cant implement another interface or class.

cards.question: T/F public abstract interface Rollable() is redundant?
cards.answer: True; abstract is assumed and not necessary in signature. public is required if you dont want it to have default access

cards.question: Valid Interface method? abstract public void bounce();
Valid Interface method? public abstract void bounce();
Valid Interface method? abstract void bounce();
Valid Interface method? public void bounce();
Valid Interface method? void bounce();
Are these all the same? void bounce(); public void bounce(); abstract void bounce(); public abstract void bounce(); abstract public void bounce();
Compiles? final void bounce();
cards.answer: False, final and abstract can never be used

cards.question: Compiles? private void bounce();
cards.answer: False, interface methods are always public

cards.question: Compiles? protected void bounce()
cards.answer: False, interface methods are always public

cards.question: T/F Interface methods are always public?
Interface Constants Are implied public static final?
cards.answer: True, you don't have to put them they are implied. public int, static int, final int, or any other combination are the same as regular int = blah.

cards.question: Interface constants must be public static final?
cards.answer: True, they are ALWAYS even when implied, to be public, static, and final

cards.question: T/F The default keyword can be used ONLY with interface method signatures not class method signatures?
T/F default methods are public by definition, the public modifier is optional
T/F Default methods can not be marked private, protected, static, final, or abstract
T/F Default methods MUST have a concrete method body
Valid default method? default void m4();
cards.answer: False, it doesn't have a concrete method body

cards.question: Valid default method? static default void m3(){;}
cards.answer: False, default methods can not be static

cards.question: Valid default method? public default void m2(){;}
Valid default method? default int m1(){return 1;}
cards.answer: True, here the default implies public

cards.question: T/F Java 8 allows static interface methods?
cards.answer: True; and they are implied public

cards.question: T/F static interface methods are public by default, and the public modifier is optional.
T/F static interface methods can be marked private, protected, final, or abstract
cards.answer: false, marked or not they must be public.

cards.question: T/F Static interface methods must have a concrete method body?
Valid static interface method? static int m1(){ return 42; }
Valid static interface method? public static void m2(){ ; }
Valid static interface method? final static void m3(){ ; }
Valid static interface method? abstract static void m4(){ ; }
Valid static interface method? static void m5();
cards.answer: False, no method body was specified

cards.question: Name the two modifiers allowed for a class.
Name the four access modifiers for methods and variables.
How do you get the default modifier on a method or variable or class
cards.answer: default is default, you don't put anything.

cards.question: What are the three ways to access a method?
cards.answer: 1) Invoke a method declared in the same class, 2) Invoke a method using a reference of a class, 3) Invoke an inherited method

cards.question: T/F A method marked final in a super class can be overridden in a sub class
cards.answer: False, compiler error cannoit override error will occur.

cards.question: T/F Abstract methods can exist in a non-abstract class
cards.answer: False, if you mark a method abstract you must mark the class abstract also.

cards.question: T/F abstract methods in a super class can have an implementation?
cards.answer: False, abstract methods by definition are abstract and you must implement them yourself in a subclass.

cards.question: T/F super class constructor is called even when not specified with super() in sub class?
cards.answer: True; in Java the constructor from the super class is called when you instantiate the base class.

cards.question: T/F You can make a inherited method private in a subclass?
cards.answer: False, you get a weaker access privilege exception at compile time.

cards.question: T/F Methods marked private are accessible only in that class?
T/F Private methods in super classes are accessible in subclasses?
cards.answer: False, only private methods are visible to the class that holds it.

cards.question: T/F Always look at the class first when determining access control?
cards.answer: True, if the class isn't accessible you know the methods/variables are also not visible.

cards.question: T/F A method marked private can NOT be overridden?
T/F This method signature will compile? static void public main(String[] args)
cards.answer: False, you get identifier expected and return type required compile errors.

cards.question: T/F Overriding depends on inheritence
T/F public static is the same thing as static public?
cards.answer: True, in the method signature you can put the access modifier before or after the static or final keyword

cards.question: How do you access a super class method from a subclass in a different package?
cards.answer: Mark it public or protected so the subclass has access to it. Default WILL not work.

cards.question: T/F javac will compile dependencies automatically (imported classes for example).
cards.answer: True; if you run javac on a class that imports another the compiler will recompile that other class too.

cards.question: T/F You can access a default variable in a superclass from a subclass?
cards.answer: False; same method rules apply, if not public or protected you have to be in the same package to access the variable.

cards.question: T/F super class protected methods/variables can be accessed with a new object of that type created?
cards.answer: False; protected only works for subclasses outside the same package.

cards.question: T/F A protected member has essentially paackage level aka default access to all classes except subclasses
T/F Subclasses outside the package can inherit a protected member?
T/F Subclasses outside the package can instantiate and reference a superclass protected member?
cards.answer: True; it must be accessed via the subclass dot notation otherwise instantiating the super class will fail to work on that member.

cards.question: T/F A class that instantiates another object which inherits a protected member can access that member?
cards.answer: False; the subclass has access, but to all else it is private. So the compiler errors out about protected access in the original super class.

cards.question: T/F Default members are visible to subclasses ONLY if those subclasses are in the same package as the superclass?
T/F Access modifiers can be applied to local variables?
cards.answer: False, these will not compile and isn't allowed

cards.question: T/F Access modifiers can be applied to instance variables?
T/F final modifier can be applied to local variables?
cards.answer: True, and it is the only one :)

cards.question: Which of these has access (public/private/protected/default) : From the same class
cards.answer: All, public private protected and default

cards.question: Which of these has access (public/private/protected/default) : From any class in the same package
Which of these has access (public/private/protected/default) : From a subclass in the same package
Which of these has access (public/private/protected/default) : From a subclass outside the same package
Which of these has access (public/private/protected/default) : From any nonsubclass class outside the package
